coredata.dc:title: Temperature dependence of the relaxation rate constants of the a 1Δg and b 1Σ + g states of oxygen isotopes
coredata.dc:creator: Plötz, J.
Maier, Max
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The relaxation rate constants of the low-lying electronic singlet states, a 1Δg and b 1Σ+ g , of gaseous natural O2 and of the isotope 18O2 were investigated as a function of temperature from 100 to 295 K. The measured increase of the rate constants with temperature is in good agreement with a theory of electronic-to-vibrational-translational energy transfer. The significant effects of the different electronic states and of the isotope masses on the absolute values of the relaxation rate constants, which range from 1.0× 10−20 to 3.9× 10−17 s−1 molecule−1 cm3 at 295 K, are discussed.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 138, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 31 July 1987 TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE OF THE RELAXATION RATE CONSTANTS OF THE a 'Ag AND b 'Zg STATES OF OXYGEN ISOTOPES J. PLOTZ and Max MAIER Naturwissenschafthche Fakultat II - Physik, Vniversitat Regensburg, D-8400 Regensburg, Federal Republic of Germany Received 30 April 1987; in final form 18 May 1987 The relaxation rate constants of the low-lying electronic singlet states, a 'Ag and b ' g', of gaseous natural 0; and of the isotope "Os were investigated as a function of temperature from 100 to 295 K. The measured increase of the rate constants with temper- ature is in good agreement with a theory ofelectronic-to-vibrational-translational energy transfer. The significant effects of the different electronic states and of the isotope masses on the absolute values of the relaxation rate constants, which range from l.Ox 10-20 to 3.9x 10- '7 s-' molecule-' cm3 at 295 K, are discussed. 1. Introduction There is a large number of studies of the quench- ing reactions of singlet molecular oxygen by ground- state 0-i and by various diatomic and polyatomic molecules [ 1 ]. Most of the measurements were car- ried out at room temperature. Studies of the tem- perature dependence of the relaxation rate constants have been made [2-10], which are needed for checking the existing calculations. Various theoreti- cal approaches [11-14] do not give a comprehen- sive picture of the observed quenching phenomena. The different theoretical models and the large num- ber of experimental data have been reviewed and discussed by Wayne [ 1 ]. A particular problem is the calculation of the relaxation rate constant of singlet molecular oxygen by ground-state molecular oxygen [ 12,13]. In order to solve this problem, a theory of vibrational relax- ation developed by Shin [15] was adapted to the electronic relaxation of molecular oxygen [ 16,17 ]. A review of earlier theoretical work on relaxation rate constants and a discussion of the results is given in ref. [18]. The modified theory of Shin has been suc- cessfully applied to the relaxation of singlet 0-t in liq- uid oxygen. Moreover, it was possible to fit the calculations to the measured temperature depen- dence of the Oz(a 'Ag) relaxation between 150 and 295 K [8,10]. The fitting parameter was the range parameter a of the intermolecular Morse potential used in the calculations. However, further experi- mental results are needed to check the validity of this theoretical approach. In this Letter, we present a study of the temper- ature dependence of the collisional quenching of the low-lying excited electronic singlet states of molec- ular oxygen, O^a'Ag) and O^b'Zg^), for natural oxygen, which contains 99.8% "O, and for the iso- tope '*0-t. The aim of the work is to gain insight into the mechanism of electronic-to-vibrational-trans- lational energy transfer by a quantitative compari- son of the experimental results with the theoretical approach of refs. [ 15-17 ]. In particular, the observed effects of the two different electronic singlet states and of the molecular masses on the absolute values of the relaxation rate constant of oxygen and on the temperature dependence of the collisional quench- ing are discussed in detail. 2. Theoretical model The calculations are based on the isolated binary collision (IBC) model. The relaxation rate constant is written as k=PZ. (I) Here, P is the transition probability per collision and 0 009-2614/87/$ 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) 419 Volume 138, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 31 July 1987 Z is the number of collisions per second. For the calculation of the transition probability P the relaxation routes of the electronic states must be known. Most of the energy of the 'Ag state is trans- ferred to vibrational levels of the electronic ground state of the colliding molecules [ 1,16]. A small part of the electronic energy, the energy mismatch A y, is transferred to translational motion. The ' g' state has been shown [1,17] to be quenched by collisions to vibrational levels of the 'Ag state. The values of the energy mismatch A y of the most probable relax- ation channels of the 'Ag and ' ^ states are given in table 1. A y is smaller for "O; than for ^Oz, because of the isotope effect in the vibrational frequency. We use a modified theory of vibrational relaxation [15,18] to calculate the transition probabilities for the collisional deactivation of singlet molecular oxy- gen. The attractive and repulsive forces between the molecules are taken into account by the Morse potential U(r, e, a), where e is the depth of the potential and a is a measure of the range of the inter- molecular forces. The probability P^vm-r that dur- ing a binary collision, molecule I will change its vibrational state from 0 to v, while simultaneously molecule II will change its vibrational state from 0 to v^-v is given by [16-18] Poo .^-.=P[VO v(l)}2[VO^-VW]2 (2) The sum Vm of the vibrational quantum numbers of the excited levels of the molecules after the collision is taken to be 5 and 3 for the 'Ag and 'S^ states, respectively, because then the energy mismatch A y has its minimum value. The factor P contains the steric factors and the electronic matrix elements. For simplicity, we set P= 1 in the calculations. The vibrational factor (V'^)2 is the square of the matrix element of the transition between the vibra- tional states ; and/ For a harmonic oscillator we get [18] [I/0.i(I)p^O.^-t.(U)]2 =(fla2/4n)vm{mlAVl)-v(mn^Vn)~{l'm~v) (3) Table 1 Energy mismatch A v of the most probable relaxation route, normalized collision energy E*/ksTand normalized relaxation distance /( /CTuofthe 'Agand 'Sg^ states of natural 0; and the isotope "Ozat 295 K. The Lennard- Jones diameter of Oi is Uu= 0.348 nm. The transition probability P, the normalized collision frequency ZIn and the relaxation rate constant kin have been calculated using the following numbers: potential parameters a =4.5 XI O8 cm -1 and tiks = 103 K, vibrational wavenumbersAvC'OhCi.g"))^! 556.5 cm"', Ar("02('Ag))= 1483.5 cm-', ArC'Ozt^g-))^ 1468.6 cm-', AyC'OzCAg^ 1401.3 cm-', wavenumbers of electronic states, 'Ag: 7882cm-', ' ,: 13120cm-' Natural 10; "O; 'Ag '^+ 'Ag '^+ A y (cm-') 194 665 624 921 E'lk^T 1.356 3.454 3.511 4.587 R*lau 0.940 0.902 0.901 0.889 lO^pa) 0.32 77 0.00063 1.68 10"Z/n(s-' mol-' cm3) 5.4 0.61 0.54 0.18 10'8fc/?^(s-'mol-' cm3) calculated a) 1.7 47 0.00034 0.30 measured 1.7 39 0.010 8.1 ^i calc. 0.036 0.0011 meas. 0.044 0.0012 18^16^ calc. 0.00020 0.0064 meas. 0.0059 0.21 "' The calculated values of the transition probability have been adjusted to get agreement between the measured and calculated relaxation rate constant kin of natural 0;( 'Ag). 420 Volume 138, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 31 July 1987 (5) where m\ n and Ar, n are the molecular mass and the vibrational frequency, respectively. The temperature dependence of the transition probability is determined by the translational factor F, which is given by [15] _ /27iwA ^2? / 4(fflf) /2 ) 00 -)J F=[ ,-5 exp - \ a^fi2 ) J \ a-h X [g(x+AE^/e) -g(x)] -x dx, (4) with g(x) = (/CB Tx/c)\n arctg[(A:B Tx/e) '/2] -^ln(l+ksTx/e). The integration is carried out over the normalized collision energies x=ElksT. The total transition probability is obtained as the sum P=.%o-P :^-i. over the different relaxation channels. The collision frequency Z is calculated from an expression given by Einwohner and Alder [19] (6) The term in the brackets is the usual collision fre- quency Zk of the simple kinetic theory. It is multi- plied by the pair distribution function g, which depends on the distance R* between the colliding molecules where the deexcitation is assumed to occur. For a low density gas the pair distribution function is given by [10] (7) U(R*) is the intermolecular potential energy at the relaxation distance R*. For the deactivation of sin- glet Oz mainly high collision energies are important, i.e. U(R*)/kBT^.l. Therefore, the pair distribution function g( T,R*) leads to a temperature-dependent reduction of the collision frequency. For the calculation of the collision frequency Z the relaxation distance R* must be known. There is a distribution of distances R* because of the thermal distribution of the collision energies E. For simplic- ity, we use in the calculation of Z the most probable value of R*. It is obtained by calculating the most probable collision energy E* for the deactivation of singlet molecular oxygen from the integrand of eq. (4). We assume the relaxation distance R* to be close to the classical turning point of the collision and cal- culate it by equating E* with the intermolecular potential energy U(R*). Table 1 shows typical val- ues of * and R* at room temperature for the 'Ag and '^ states of natural 0; and ^Oz. If the energy A y, which is transferred to translational motion, is small (e.g. for Oz( 'Ag)), then the most probable col- lision energy E* is also small, leading to a large relax- ation distance R*. It should be noted that E*/kyT enters the collision frequency via the pair distribu- tion function g (eqs. (6) and (7)). Large values of E*/ksT (e.g. for ^Oi) cause a reduction of the col- lision frequency (see table 1). The relaxation rate constants k are calculated from eqs. (1)-(?). The numbers for the various param- eters used in the calculations are given in table 1. The results will be discussed in section 4. 3. Experimental The apparatus for the measurements has been described elsewhere [10,16,17]. High purity grade natural Oz (Linde; purity 99.999 vol%; 0.2% ^O) and '"Oz (Ventron, 99.0% ^O) were used. The 'Ag state of oxygen was excited by absorption of the light pulse of a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser. The time dependence of the 'Ag population was moni- tored by observing the double-molecule fluorescence at 635 nm with a photomultiplier. There is a strong dependence of the double-molecule fluorescence intensity /p on the number density n of the oxygen gas (/F(<=0)ocn4). Therefore, the measurements were carried out at pressures between 2.5 and 10 MPa. Sufficient gas pressure was available only for temperatures T ^ 140 K. (critical point T^= 154.6 K). In the pressure range used in the experiments the relaxation rate constants k were proportional to the gas density n. The laser energy density was chosen low enough to get an exponential time decay of the fluorescence intensity. OzCSg^) was generated by a ruby-laser-pumped dye laser with a wavelength of 762.2 nm. The ' g' population was observed using the fluorescence emission at 864.8 nm and 858.3 nm of natural 0; and ^Oz, respectively, which is due to the transition lI.^(v=0)^I,^(v=l)+hv. The fluorescence intensity decreases only slightly with falling gas den- 421 Volume 138, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 31 July 1987 sity (/F(?=O) ocn'2, from 0.1 to 10 MPa). Sufficient fluorescence intensity was obtained at a gas pressure of about 0.2 MPa. Therefore, the relaxation rate con- stant ofO^C^g) could be measured down to T= 100 K. 4. Results and discussion The measured and calculated relaxation rate con- stants kin of the 'Ag and 'Eg' states of natural Oz and ^Oz at room temperature (T=295 K) and the values of the parameters used in the calculations are given in table 1. The value of the potential parameter a=4.5xl08 cm"' has been used, because it gives best agreement between the measured and calculated normalized temperature dependence of all four spe- cies (see below). The absolute values of the calcu- lated rate constants have been adjusted to the measured value of natural OzCAg). The measured relaxation rate constants of natural O^CAg) and 0;>(' 5^) at 295 K agree with literature values [ 1 ]. It should be noted that the calculated rate constant of natural OaCSg^) and the calculated ratios k^/k^ of natural Oz and ^Oz are in good agreement with the measured values (see table 1). This agreement indicates that the differences in the relaxation of both singlet states are well described by the theory. The relaxation rate constants of the 'S^ state of both oxygen isotopes are larger than the corresponding values of the 'Ag state (see table 1), because the total number v^ of the vibrational quanta involved in the relaxation process is smaller for the 'Sg^ state (I'm =3) than for the 'Ag state (I'm =5). Smaller val- ues of u^ yield larger vibrational transition matrix elements (eq. (3)) and increase the transition prob- ability P (eq. (2)). The larger matrix elements of the 'Sg^ state overcompensate its smaller collision fre- quency (table 1) and its smaller translational factor F(eq. (4)). A comparison of the relaxation rate constants of natural Oz and ^Oa in table 1 shows a strong isotope effect. The rate constants of ^Oz are much smaller than those of natural 0^. both for the 'Ag state and the ' g' state. The main reason for the difference is the larger energy mismatch A \, of the isotope ^O; (see table 1), which is due to the smaller vibrational frequency because of the larger mass. Natural OzCAg): open circles, solid and dotted line; natural OzCZg'): open squares, dashed line; '"O^ '\): full circles, broken line; "O^ 'Z^): full squares, dash- dotted line. The high temperature points of natural 02 (' ^) have been taken from ref. [ 4]. has to be transferred to translational motion for ^Oz than for "Oz, decreasing the transition probability P through factor F (eq. (4)). The calculated ratios 'WA: of the rate constants of ^O; and natural 0; are much smaller than the measured ratios (see table 1). This discrepancy indicates that the isotope effect is only qualitatively described by the theory. The temperature dependence of the relaxation rate constants is presented in fig. 1, where \n(k/n) is plot- ted versus l/T. The symbols and the lines represent the experimental points and the calculated curves, respectively. The temperature dependence of the dif- ferent species cannot be described by straight lines over the entire temperature range, i.e. there is no Arrhenius dependence. It should be noted that for natural OzCZg^) there is excellent agreement between the experimental points (DM) and the cal- culated dashed line over four orders of magnitude of the relaxation rate constant. The high temperature points (E) tor natural O^C^-s) haw been taken from the work ofBorrell et al. [4]. The agreement between the experiments (0) and the calculations (solid line) is also good for natural OzCAg). How- ever, the theory gets worse below 150 K (dotted line). One of the possible reasons is that the values of the most probable collision energy E*/kfsTget small. The calculated broken and dash-dotted curves for the 'Ag state and the 'Sg' state, respectively, of the isotope 422 Volume 138, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 31 July 1987 Temperature T1KI Fig. 2. Normalized relaxation rate constants {kln}Tl(kln)t^^ versus temperature T. Natural 0;>('Ag): open circles, solid and dotted line; natural OzCZg^): open squares, dashed line; "O^ 'Ag): full circles, broken line; "Ozf' S^):full squares, dash- dotted line. 5. Conclusions The measured different temperature dependences of the relaxation rate constants of the 'Ag and 'Xg' states of gaseous natural 0; and "Oz are quantita- tively described by our theoretical model of elec- tronic-to-vibrational-translational energy transfer. The differences in the temperature dependence of the investigated species and the observed isotope effects are qualitatively explained by the different amount of electronic energy which is transferred to transla- tional motion. The larger values of the relaxation rate constants of Oz(' Sg^) compared to Oa ('Ag) are due to the fact that in the ' g' relaxation (to the 'Ag state) a smaller part of the electronic energy is transferred to vibrational energy (three vibrational quanta) than in the 'Ag relaxation (five vibrational quanta). '^O-t lie far below the experimental points ( , ), because the theory does not describe the isotope effect properly. For a detailed discussion of the temperature dependence of the electronic relaxation, we normal- ized the rate constants kin to their respective values at room temperature. The ratios ()dn)Tl(kln)^ ^ are plotted in fig. 2 versus temperature T. In the cal- culations a value of the potential parameters a=4.5xl08 cm~1 has been used which gives very good agreement between the calculated curves and the corresponding experimental points, except for 18 Oat 'Sg^). For this species the experimental points ( ) lie above the calculated curve (dash-dotted line). There is experimental evidence that in partic- ular the relaxation of ^O^' g') is most sensitive to impurities. This fact may be responsible for the observed difference in fig. 2. The temperature dependence of the relaxation rate constants of nat- ural O^'Z^) (D),'^'^) O.and'^CAJ ( ) is very similar, but the points lie far below those of natural Oz( 'Ag) (0). The reason is that these spe- cies have a larger energy mismatch AJEy than natural Oa ('Ag) (see table 1), which mainly determines the temperature dependence of the relaxation rate con- stants (via the factor F, eq. (4)). References [ 1 ] R.P. Wayne, in: Singlet Oz, Vol. 1, ed. A.A. Frimer (CRC press, Boca Raton, 1985) p. 81. [2] M. Braithwaite, E.A. Ogryzlo, J.A. Davidson and H.I. Schiff, Chem. Phys. head.ce:title: Temperature dependence of the relaxation rate constants of the a 1Δg and b 1Σ + g states of oxygen isotopes

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Naturwissenschaftliche Fakultät II - Physik, Universität Regensburg, D-8400 Regensburg, Federal Republic of Germany

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The relaxation rate constants of the low-lying electronic singlet states, a 1Δg and b 1Σ+ g , of gaseous natural O2 and of the isotope 18O2 were investigated as a function of temperature from 100 to 295 K. The measured increase of the rate constants with temperature is in good agreement with a theory of electronic-to-vibrational-translational energy transfer. The significant effects of the different electronic states and of the isotope masses on the absolute values of the relaxation rate constants, which range from 1.0× 10−20 to 3.9× 10−17 s−1 molecule−1 cm3 at 295 K, are discussed.
